5.2 Written Follow Up.
As soon as practicable after the release, a follow up written notice is to be provided to these agencies. The Treatment Operations Manager or his designee will be responsible to provide these written reports.
5.4 OSHA Notification.
In the event of a fatality or multiple hospitalization, OSHA is to be notified within 48 hours in accordance with OSHA regulations. This notification will be handled by the Human Resource Manager in accordance with CUWCD policies.
6. TRAINING
Refresher training for all personnel will be done annually in accordance with CUWCD and CWP refresher training requirements. Additional training seminars and exercise drills will be conducted as applicable and reasonable to do so in order to provide for well trained chlorine operators.

e Assistance
In the event we are unable to contain a release from a ton container, contact the supplier. If assistance cannot be obtained, contact CHLOREP through CHEMTRACT at 1-800- 429-9300. The problem should be described with the required help needed. Be certain to give your name, phone number, company name, address and other information needed. These contacts are to be made by the emergency response coordinator.
4.10 Emergency Treatment
CWP has as part of the RMP/PSM with a copy of The Chlorine Institute pamphlet #63, First Aid and Medical
Management of Chlorine Exposures.  Any injured person suffering from chlorine inhalation should be sent to the hospital. To the extent possible an injured employee should be accompanied by another employee. Notification to the family should be made as soon as practical by the plant manager or his designee, preferably following contact with the Human Resource Manager. As part of training and annual refresher training, all employees are trained in first aid procedures for chlorination contact and exposures, using as a reference chapter 6 of The
Chlorine Institute's pamphlet #1, The Chlorine Manual.
5. OUTSIDE REGULATORY AGENCY NOTIFICATION
This contact is to be made the CUWCD Treatment Operations Manager if available, or if not available, the Plant Manager. If both are unavailable, the ranking supervisor at the facility will give the immediate verbal notification.
5.1 Verbal Notification
The law requires that this Facility immediately report any releases of chlorine equal to or greater that ten (10) pounds to the following agencies:
1. National Response Center;
2. Local Emergency Planning Committee; and
3. State Emergency Planning Commission.
Information should include the following:
1. Chemical released - Chlorine;
2. Chlorine is on the Extremely Hazardous Substances List;
3. Estimate quantity released. If not sure, simply state, 10 pounds or more;
4. Time and duration of the release;

DESIGNEE IS AUTHORIZED TO RELEASE ANY INFORMATION ABOUT THE INCIDENT TO THE MEDIA. ANY PERSON DISCUSSING THE INCIDENT WITH THE MEDIA MUST NOT SPECULATE AS TO THE CAUSE OF THE INCIDENT. IF THE CAUSE IS KNOWN, SO ADVISE THE MEDIA. IF THE CAUSE IS NOT KNOWN, ADVISE THE MEDIA IT IS UNDER INVESTIGATION. NORMALLY THE QUANTITY OF CHLORINE EMITTED DURING A RELEASE IS UNKNOWN UNTIL A THOROUGH INVESTIGATION IS COMPLETE. IF SUCH IS THE CASE, SO ADVISE THE MEDIA.
When dealing with the media remember to be honest, courteous, straight forward, and concerned. Do not speculate. Do not give off the record comments.
4.8 Shelter/Evacuation
Even though this facility will be working closely with the LEPC, Fire Department, and other emergency officials, a decision regarding whether to evacuate or to shelter affected outside persons is a difficult one. Generally for us, a significant chlorine release is likely to last for up to one hour before it is contained.  Therefore, sheltering in place is the normal mode to be utilized during an emergency. While it is unlikely that this facility could have a chlorine release requiring evacuation, nevertheless, we must be prepared for such an eventually. If it is anticipated that a release cannot be soon contained or is of a massive quantity, the evacuation option should be utilized. Call 911 and suggest that sheltering of residences within (indicate immediate area or more as needed) and evacuation of others be implemented.
4.8.1 Neighboring Residences and Facilities
There are no residences close to this facility.
4.8.2 Responsibility
These duties are the responsibility of the overall emergency coordinator. He may choose to delegate some or all of these duties to another competent person. It is also quite probable that the responding agency or agencies will establish a command post and appoint a Incident Commander to assume these responsibilities, especially in regard to those affected areas outside the plant grounds.

ly staffed only from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m. five days a week. The plant is on line 24 hours a day and is fully computerized. The computers constantly control and monitor the plant and are connected to sensors in the chlorine storage and process areas. The computers monitor for any chlorine release and will react to a release by going into an alarm condition. The computers are programed to call out to the On Call Operator during the non-working hours and alert the On Call Operator with a voice message programed to indicate the nature of the plant alarm including a possible chlorine release. Upon receiving a possible chlorine release alarm, the Operator will then proceed to the plant, alerting all other plant employees by cellular phone on the way. All plant employees contacted are to proceed to the plant to give assistance.
4.6 Outside Assistance
The overall emergency coordinator will meet or will delegate an available person to meet at the front gate and escort any outside responders notified by the coordinator to assist in the response. If the front gate is not accessible, the responders should be met at the public road upwind of the release.
4.7 Media Inquiry
Media inquiries should be handled, as time permits, by the emergency response coordinator or other CUWCD management personnel. Arriving media representatives should be allowed to wait at the front gate until escorted into the main office when accessible and time permits. Under no conditions is the front entrance allowed to become blocked to hinder the passage of emergency responders and plant employees. No one other than plant employees and emergency responders are allowed access to the plant grounds at anytime during the emergency without prior authorization. When time permits, the media should be given background information on chlorine. When facts are known about the incident and the cause, these should be given to the media. c. Determine the need for emergency containment team.
The emergency containment team will be made up of trained CUWCD employees from both plants as needed. The senior CWP employee present will be the team leader. Team members must wear SCBA and follow proper procedures. This team will investigate to determine the source and extent of the leak. This team will take actions to make an initial containment of the release if determined reasonable to do so.
d. Determine the need for outside assistance and/or notification.
As overall emergency response coordinator, the Plant Manager, or in his absence the On Duty Operator, is authorized to notify directly or through delegation, the appropriate outside agencies/neighbors. This may include the fire department, police/sheriff department, Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC), industrial and/or residential neighbors, and anyone else who might provide assistance in responding to the emergency or who might be affected by it. Notify CUWCD management in Orem as soon as it is reasonably possible to do so.
e. The On Duty Operator (On Call Operator after hours) is designated backup to the Plant Manager and is responsible for performing all the duties in the event of the unavailability of the Plant Manager.
4.4 Telephone Answering
Any requests from the media are to be referred to the emergency response coordinator. If that person is unavailable, take the person's name, organization, and phone number. Persons assigned to answer the phone are not authorized to discuss the incident with the media or with any other callers except people involved with the emergency response. Simply state We have had an emergency. We are responding to it now (or it is now ended). Someone from our plant will return your call as soon as possible if you will give me your name, organization, and phone number. I am not authorized to give you any information. Give your name if asked.

1-PURPOSE
The purpose of the CWP Vineyard Emergency Response
Plan (ERP) is to effectively respond to a chlorine release to minimize injuries, lessen the impact in the community, minimize damage to the treatment plant, and provide guidance to local emergency response personnel. All employees at CWP are trained in chlorine containment procedures and all are trained in the use of SCBA equipment.

2-TYPES OF EMERGENCY
a. Chlorine Release
In the event of an equipment or human failure, potential sources for chlorine releases are:
1. One Ton chlorine Container
2. Chlorine supply lines and chlorination equipment.
At this facility, the loss of any utilities including electricity will not increase the potential for a chlorine release.

3-SCOPE
The scope of this plan includes:
a. A chlorine release contained within the plant facilities and controllable by
CUWCD personnel and equipment.
b. A chlorine release affecting or with the potential to affect the area surrounding the
CUWCD; such a release would require outside assistance.

4-PLANNING FOR HANDLING THE EMERGENCY
Responsibility:
The Plant Manager is ultimately responsible for the implementation of the plan. He is responsible for keeping the plan current and insuring that all plant employees are properly trained.
Initiating the ER (Emergency Response Plan)
The ERP is initiated by any employee at any time in response to a known or perceived chlorine release. Initiating employee will notify all other personnel at the plant (if any) by best means possible (i.e. intercom, cell phone, two way radio, or in person).
4.2 Assembly Area
Primary --Control Room
Secondary --Front Gate Area
